fields.summary: [C++][Compute] Test failures with gcc-9.3 on aarch64

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
When building libraries for avx512 with GCC 7.3.0, two C++ tests fails.
{noformat}
The following tests FAILED: 
  28 - arrow-compute-compare-test (Failed) 
  30 - arrow-compute-filter-test (Failed) 
Errors while running CTest{noformat}
while for avx2 they passes.
fields.environment: CentOS 7.6.1810, Intel Xeon Processor (Skylake, IBRS) avx512

comments.body:
Thanks for the report. Can you include detailed test output?

Also, it would be even better if you could investigated the underlying cause.

[~coulombec] would you be willing to investigate this? I don't think any of us has access to a AVX512 machine.

[~wesmckinn]
I have an avx512 machine (i9-9960X). I can create an account for you and give SSH access (without root) if you like
If the machine is accross the Atlantic that may not be optimal :)
Ah, if you use mosh instead of ssh the latency is acceptable (I'm using it from California at the moment and it seems pretty okay) =)
Well, let's create that account :-) Does it have a stable IP address?
It does. I'll create an account, add your SSH keys (https://github.com/pitrou.keys) and send you the connection information privately
[~coulombec] I tried to reproduce ("{{-march=skylake-avx512}}")  with gcc 7.4.0 and 8.3.0. Can you explain precisely what you did?

[~apitrou] sorry for the lack of comments, theses emails ended up being filtered. I'll be able to respond quicker now.

I could also provide an AVX512 machine with our build environment if you'd like (in North America). 
I work at Compute Canada and we use a build system called EasyBuild. It will be easier to share the full log instead so here it is. It contains tests output and build steps (and their stdout) : [^easybuild-arrow-0.14.1-20190809.111134.MgMEK.log]
 Let me know if the tests could be more verbose, I could rerun it with different options.

I'll try to find some time in the coming weeks to dig into this but I do not know the internals of Arrow.
Ok, I tried with the precise C++ and C flags you used and still cannot reproduce (on Ubuntu 18.04, gcc 7.4.0).

To help debugging this, I suggest focussing on {{arrow-compute-compare-test}}. You could run the test standalone from the command line instead of going through {{ctest}}.

You could do the following: open {{cpp/src/arrow/compute/kernels/compare_test.cc}}; go to the {{RandomCompareArrayScalar}} function and log the values of variables {{i}} and {{op}} (for example using C or C++ printing).

If you don't want to do this, you can give me access to the machine but you'll have to explain me how to build. Is it a normal Unix environment?
Ok, will try what you suggests. I'll keep you posted.
[~coulombec] Any update here? Did you try to investigate?

Yes I did, and I tried with v0.15.1, which also fails the same two tests.

As you suggested, I logged the {{i}} and {{op}} values, for arrow-compute-compare-test : [^arrow-compute-compare-test.res]

I also added a script that better describe the environment used to build Arrow : [^arrow-0.15.1-GCC-7.3.0.env.avx512]

Ok. The failures only happen in {{RandomCompareArrayScalar}}, only when {{i >= 9}} meaning the array length is >= 512 elements (regardless of the data type). I think the only likely explanation is a compiler bug.

I would recommend trying a different compiler version and/or tweaking the compile options. What happens if you remove {{-ftree-vectorize}}?

Also cc [~bkietz]

Just got the results for GCC 9.1.0 and all tests passes! :D 

-Still waiting for- GCC 8.3.0 ... and all tests passes.
Ok, I think we can close it as a non-Arrow bug then. Thanks for investigating.
